zlel package

Submodules

zlel.zlel_p1 module

zlel.zlel_p1.MNUs(cir_el, cir_val, cir_ctr, b, denbora, V, h, g)[source]

This function creates the M, N and Us matrices that are necessary to form the Tableau equations.

Args:
cir_el: np array of strings with the elements to parse. size(1,b)
cir_val: np array with the values of the elements. size(b,3)
cir_ctrl: np array of strings with the element which branch
b: dimensions of cir_el.
denbora: argument for account time, necessary for dinamic circuits.
V: List of voltages of non-linear elements.
h: Time step.
g: Matrix formed by g =[[g11,g12],[g21,g22]], neccesary for solving circuits with transistors.
Returns:
M: “Voltage matrix”.
N: “Current matrix”.
Us: Vector of non V controlled elements.
zlel.zlel_p1.cir_parser(filename)[source]

This function takes a .cir test circuit and parse it into 4 matices. If the file has not the proper dimensions it warns and exit. This function also ensures that the cir does not contain any of the following errors:

There is a reference node defined.
There are no floating nodes.
There are no parallel V sources.
There are no serial I sources.
Args:

filename: string with the name of the file

Returns:
cir_el: np array of strings with the elements to parse. size(1,b)
cir_nd: np array with the nodes to the circuit. size(b,4)
cir_val: np array with the values of the elements. size(b,3)
cir_ctrl: np array of strings with the element which branch
controls the controlled sources. size(1,b)
Rises:

SystemExit

zlel.zlel_p1.ez_linealak(cir_el)[source]

function that cheks if there are any diodes or transistors.

Args:

cir_el: matrix got when parsing the circuit (circuit elements).

Returns:

j: The number of non lineal elements.

ezlin: matrix with the non lineal elements.

zlel.zlel_p1.incidence(cir_nd, nodes, n, b)[source]

Creates an incidence matrix based on the reshaped cir_nd.

Args:

cir_nd: The reshaped cir_nd.

nodes: An array containing all of the different nodes.

n: The number of nodes.

b: The number of branches.

Returns:

matrix: The incidence matrix.

zlel.zlel_p1.print_cir_info(cir_el, cir_nd, b, n, nodes, el_num)[source]
Prints the info of the circuit:
1.- Elements info
2.- Node info
3.- Branch info
4.- Variable info
Args:
cir_el: reshaped cir_el
cir_nd: reshaped cir_nd. Now it will be a(b,2) matrix
b: number of branches
n: number of nodes
nodes: an array with the circuit nodes sorted
el_num: the number of elements
zlel.zlel_p1.reshape(cir_el, cir_nd, cir_val, cir_ctr)[source]

Function that will resize the two matrix by taking into account if there are any transistros or OPAMP

Args:

cir_el: matrix got when parsing the circuit (circuit elements).

cir_nd: matrix got when parsing the circuit (nodes of each element)

Returns:

reshaped cir_el and cir_nd matrixes

zlel.zlel_p2 module

zlel.zlel_p2.Tableau(a, M, N, Us)[source]

This function evaluates the Tableau equations, using the M,N and Us matrices and the A incidence matrix.

Args:
M: Voltage matrix.
N: Current matrix.
Us: Vector of non V controlled elements.
Returns:
T: Tableau matrix, formed by all Tableau equations, in order e,…,v,…,i.

Sol: List of all Tableau equation solutions, in order e,…,v,…,i

zlel.zlel_p2.build_csv_header(tvi, b, n)[source]

This function builds the csv header for the files.

First column will be v or i if .dc analysis or t if .tr and it will be given by argument tvi. The header will be this form, t/v/i,e_1,..,e_n-1,v_1,..,v_b,i_1,..i_b

Args:
tvi: “v” or “i” if .dc analysis or “t” if .tran
b: # of branches
n: # of nodes
Returns:

header: The header in csv format as string

zlel.zlel_p2.plot_from_cvs(filename, x, y, title)[source]

This function plots the values corresponding to the x string of the file filename in the x-axis and the ones corresponding to the y string in the y-axis. The x and y strings must mach with some value of the header in the csv file filename.

Args:
filename: string with the name of the file (including the path).
x: string with some value of the header of the file.
y: string with some value of the header of the file.
zlel.zlel_p2.print_solution(sol, b, n)[source]

This function prints the solution with format.

Args:
sol: np array with the solution of the Tableau equations
(e_1,..,e_n-1,v_1,..,v_b,i_1,..i_b)
b: # of branches
n: # of nodes
zlel.zlel_p2.save_as_csv(b, n, filename, matrize, tvi)[source]

This function gnerates a csv file with the name filename. First it will save a header and then, it loops and save a line in csv format into the file.

Args:
b: # of branches
n: # of nodes
filename: string with the filename (incluiding the path)

zlel.zlel_p3 module

zlel.zlel_p3.Ebatzi_denak(filename, cir_val_dc, hasiera, h)[source]

Function that returns the solution of the Tableau equations receiving the filename of a .cir.

Args:
filename: Name of the file of the .cir.
cir_val_dc: The new cir_val, necessary for updating the cir_val matrix in .dc.
hasiera: argument for account time necessary for dinamic circuits.
h: Time step.
Returns:

Sol:List of all Tableau equation solutions,in order e,…,v,…,i.

b: dimensions of cir_el.
n: cir_el length.
g: Matrix formed by g=[[g11,g12],[g21,g22]], neccesary for solving circuits with transistors.
V: List of voltages of non-linear elements.
zlel.zlel_p3.Transistor_NR(V, indizeak, epsilon, j, filename, cir_val_new, hasiera, h)[source]

Calculates the g-s,VBe and VBc of a transistor for a NR discrete equivalent Given,

\(g_{11} = -I_{es} / V_t * e^{V_{Be} / V_t}\)

\(g_{22} = -I_{cs} / V_t * e^{V_{Bc} / V_t}\)

\(g_{12} = -a_r * g_{22}\)

\(g_{21} = -a_f * g_{11}\)

\(a_f = Bf / (1 + Bf)\)

\(a_r = Ies * af / Ics\)

\(I_e = g_{11} * V_{Be}+ g_{12} * V_{Bc}+ I_{es} *\) \((e^{V_{Be} / V_t} - 1)- a_r * I_{cs} *\) \((e^{V_{Bc} / V_t} - 1)\)

\(Ic = g21 * VBe+ g22 * VBc- af * Ies *\) \((e^{V_{Be} / V_t} - 1)+ Ics * (e^{V_{Bc} / V_t} - 1)\)

The NR discrete equivalent will be:

\(i_e+g_{11}*V_{Be}+g_{12}*V_{Bc}=I_e\)

\(i_c+g_{21}*V_{Be}+g_{22}*V_{Bc}=I_c\)

Args:
V: List of voltages of non-linear elements.
Indizeak: List of index of the non-linear elements on the matrix cir_el.
epsilon: Accuracy for the NR function.
j: Index of the non-linear element that is getting evaluated.
filename: Name of the file of the .cir.
cir_val_new: The new cir_val, necessary for updating the cir_val matrix in .dc.
hasiera: argument for account time, necessary for dinamic circuits.
h: Time step.
Returns:
g:Matrix formed by g=[[g11,g12],[g21,g22]],neccesary for solving circuits with transistors.
V: List of voltages of non-linear elements.
Boolean.
zlel.zlel_p3.diode_NR(V, indizeak, epsilon, j, filename, cir_val_new, hasiera, h)[source]

Calculates the g and the I of a diode for a NR discrete equivalent. Given,

\(Id = I_0(e^{(\frac{V_d}{nV_T})}-1)\)

The NR discrete equivalent will be,

\(i_{j+1} + g v_{j+1} = I\)

where,

\(g = -\frac{I_0}{nV_T}e^{(\frac{V_d}{nV_T})}\)

and

\(I = I_0(e^{(\frac{V_{dj}}{nV_T})}-1) + gV_{dj}\)

Args:

V: List of voltages of non-linear elements.

Indizeak: List of index of the non-linear elements on the matrix cir_el.
epsilon: Accuracy for the NR function.
j: Index of the non-linear element that is getting evaluated.
filename: Name of the file of the .cir.
cir_val_new: The new cir_val, necessary for updating the cir_val matrix in .dc.
hasiera: argument for account time, necessary for dinamic circuits.
h: Time step.
Returns:
gd: Conductance of the NR discrete equivalent for the diode.
Id: Current independent source of the NR discrete equivalent.
V: List of voltages of non-linear elements.
Boolean: used if there are more than one diode.
